{{also|-ein|ein-|EIN|éin}} ==Bourguignon== ===Etymology=== From {{inh|roa-brg|la|unus}}. ===Article=== {{head|roa-brg|article|feminine|eine|plural|des|negative|de}} # [[a]], [[an]] ---- ==Breton== ===Noun=== {{head|br|noun form}} # {{plural of|br|oan}} ---- ==Dutch Low Saxon== ===Pronunciation=== * {{IPA|nds-nl|/ˈɛɪ̯n/|/ˈaɪ̯n/}} ===Article=== {{head|nds-nl|article|g=m|indefinite article}} # {{alternative spelling of|nds-nl|een|nodot=1}} : [[a]], [[an]] ===Article=== {{head|nds-nl|article|g=n|indefinite article}} # {{alternative spelling of|nds-nl|een|nodot=1}} : [[a]], [[an]] ===Numeral=== {{head|nds-nl|numeral|cat2=cardinal numbers}} # {{alternative spelling of|nds-nl|een|nodot=1}} : [[one]] (1) ---- ==Faroese== {{cardinalbox|fo|0|1|2|null|tveir|ord=fyrsti|dis=einir}} ===Etymology=== From {{inh|fo|non|einn}}, from {{inh|fo|gem-pro|*ainaz}}, from {{inh|fo|ine-pro|*óynos}}. ===Article=== {{head|fo|article|neuter|eitt}} # [[a]], [[an]] #: {{ux|fo|'''ein''' góður maður|a good man|inline=1}} #: {{ux|fo|'''ein''' góð kvinna|a good woman|inline=1}} #: {{ux|fo|'''eitt''' gott barn|a good child|inline=1}} #: {{ux|fo|'''einir''' góðir skógvar|a good pair of shoes|inline=1}} ====Declension==== {{fo-decl-ein}} ===Numeral=== {{head|fo|numeral|neuter|eitt|cat2=cardinal numbers}} # [[one]] (1) #: {{ux|fo|'''ein''' maður og tvær kvinnur|one man and two women|inline=1}} #: {{ux|fo|'''ein''' kvinna og tveir menn|one woman and two men|inline=1}} #: {{ux|fo|'''einar''' buksur og tveir skógvar|one pair of trousers and two pair of shoes|inline=1}} #: {{ux|fo|'''ein''' dagin|one day, someday}} ====Usage notes==== When counting, use the neuter forms: {{m|fo|[[eitt]], [[tvey]], [[trý]], ...}} ===Adjective=== {{head|fo|adjective|neuter|eitt|plural|einar}} # [[same]] #: {{ux|fo|Teir fóru allir '''ein''' veg.|They all went the same way.}} # [[alone]] #: {{ux|fo|Hon sat í borgin '''ein'''.|She sat in the castle alone.}} # [[approximate]] #: {{ux|fo|'''einar''' hundrað krónur|approximately 100 kroner|inline=1}} ===Pronoun=== {{head|fo|pronoun|neuter|eitt}} # [[one]] #: {{ux|fo|'''ein''' sigur|one says|inline=1}} ====Derived terms==== * {{l|fo|ein og hvør|t=everybody}} * {{l|fo|eitt nú|t=for instance}} ---- ==Finnish== ===Noun=== {{head|fi|noun form}} # {{fi-form of|case=instructive|pl=plural|ee}} ===Anagrams=== * {{anagrams|fi|a=ein|ien}} ---- ==German== ===Alternative forms=== * {{l|de|ain}} {{qualifier|for the article, dated}} * {{l|de|'n}} {{qualifier|for the article, in informal writing}} * {{l|de|Ein}} {{qualifier|for the numeral}} * {{l|de|éin}} {{qualifier|for the numeral, rare}} ===Etymology=== From {{inh|de|gmh|ein}}, from {{inh|de|goh|ein}}, from {{inh|de|gem-pro|*ainaz}}, from {{inh|de|ine-pro|*óynos}}. Compare {{cog|nds-de|en}}, {{m|nds-de|ein}}, {{cog|nl|een}}, {{cog|en|one}}, {{cog|da|en}}, {{cog|nn|ein}}. ===Pronunciation=== * {{IPA|de|/aɪ̯n/}} {{a|standard}} * {{IPA|de|/ən/|/n̩/}} {{a|for the article, chiefly colloquial}} * {{audio|de|De-ein.ogg|audio}} * {{rhymes|de|aɪ̯n}} ===Numeral=== {{head|de|numeral|g=m|g2=n|cat2=cardinal numbers}} # [[one]] #: {{ux|de|Ich hatte nur '''ein''' Bier bestellt.|I had ordered just '''one''' beer.}} ====Usage notes==== * In counting, the form {{m|de|eins}} is used: {{m|de|'''eins''' zu [[null]]|t=one–nil}} (sport result). The name of the number ''one'', as a noun, is {{m|de|Eins}}. * In order to distinguish the numeral ("one") from the indefinite article ("a, an"), the former may be printed in [[italics]]: Ich hatte nur ''ein'' Bier bestellt. ===Article=== {{head|de|article|g=m|g2=n}} # [[a]], [[an]] #: {{ux|de|'''ein''' Mann|a man|inline=1}} #: {{ux|de|eine Frau|a woman|inline=1}} #: {{ux|de|'''ein''' Kind|a child|inline=1}} ====Usage notes==== * In the vernacular, the diphthong ''ei-'' is usually not pronounced in the indefinite article, which gives rise to the informal contractions {{m|de|'n}}, {{m|de|'ne}}, {{m|de|'nem}}, {{m|de|'ner}} ''(dative)'', and {{m|de|'nen}}. (There are no contracted genitive forms.) * Earlier contracted forms which are not in use anymore are ''{{l|de|eim}}'' for ''{{l|de|einem}}'' and ''{{l|de|eins}}'' for ''{{l|de|eines}}'' (as in "eins Mann[e]s", "eins Kind[e]s"). Even older forms are ''ein'' for ''{{l|de|eine}}'' (as in ''ein Frau''), ''{{l|de|einm}}'' for ''{{l|de|einem}}'' and ''{{l|de|einr}}'' for ''{{l|de|einer}}''. ====Declension==== {{de-decl-ein}} ====Coordinate terms==== {{de-cardinal}} ===Adjective=== {{de-adj|-}} # {{lb|de|predicative}} [[on]] ===Related terms=== * {{l|de|einer}} ===Anagrams=== * {{l|de|nie}} {{topics|de|One}} ---- ==German Low German== ===Alternative forms=== * {{l|nds-de|een}} * {{l|nds-de|en}} ===Pronunciation=== * {{IPA|nds-de|/ˈɛɪ̯n/|/ˈaɪ̯n/}} ===Article=== {{head|nds-de|article|g=m|g2=n|indefinite article}} # {{alternative spelling of|nds-de|en|t=a, an}} ===Numeral=== {{head|nds-de|numeral|cat2=cardinal numbers}} # {{alternative spelling of|nds-de|en|t=one (1)}} ---- ==Icelandic== ===Adverb=== {{head|is|adverb}} # [[alone]] #: {{ux|is|Hún er '''ein'''.|She is alone.}} ===Numeral=== {{head|is|numeral form}} # {{inflection of|is|einn||nom|n|s|;|nom//acc|n|p}} ===Anagrams=== * {{l|is|nei}} ---- ==Japanese== ===Romanization=== {{ja-romaji}} # {{ja-romanization of|えいん}} ---- ==Norwegian Nynorsk== ===Etymology=== From {{inh|nn|non|einn}}, from {{inh|nn|gem-pro|*ainaz}}, from {{inh|nn|ine-pro|*óynos}}. Akin to {{cog|en|one|}}, {{cog|en|an}} ===Pronunciation=== * {{IPA|nn|/æɪn/}} {{nn-pronu-note}} ===Numeral=== {{head|nn|numeral|g=m|feminine|ei|neuter|eitt|stressed masculine|éin|stressed feminine|éi}} # {{cln|nn|cardinal numbers}} [[one]] (cardinal number 1) ====Derived terms==== * {{l|nn|eindimensjonal}} * {{l|nn|einføtt}} * {{l|nn|einstøing}} ===Article=== {{head|nn|article|g=m|indefinite singular feminine|ei|indefinite singular neuter|eit|definite singular|-en|indefinite plural|-ar|definite plural|-ane}} # [[w:Nynorsk#Nouns|Indefinite singular article for masculine nouns.]] # [[a]], [[an]] (indefinite article) #: {{ux|nn|Eg skal selja '''ein''' båt.|I am going to sell '''a''' boat.}} #: {{ux|nn|'''Ein''' raud blome.|'''A''' red flower.}} ===Pronoun=== {{head|nn|pronoun}} # [[one]] (impersonal pronoun) # [[one]] (indefinite personal pronoun) #: {{ux|nn|'''Ein''' skal ikkje tru på alt ein høyrer.|'''One''' should not believe everything one is told.}} # {{l|en|someone}} #: {{ux|nn|Eg kjenner '''ein''' som kan spela trombone.|I know '''someone''' who can play the trombone.}} ===Adverb=== {{head|nn|adverb}} # [[circa]], [[approximately]], [[about]] #: {{ux|nn|Det ligg '''ein''' to-tre kilometer unna.|It lies '''about''' two to three kilometres away.}} ===See also=== * {{l-nb|en}} ===References=== * {{R:The Nynorsk Dictionary}} ---- ==Old High German== {{cardinalbox|goh|0|1|2||zwene}} ===Etymology=== From {{inh|goh|gem-pro|*ainaz}}, whence also {{cog|ang|ān}}, {{cog|non|einn}}. Ultimately from {{inh|goh|ine-pro|*óynos}}. ===Numeral=== {{head|goh|numeral}} # {{cln|goh|cardinal numbers}} [[one]] ===Adverb=== {{goh-adv}} #[[only]] ====Descendants==== * {{desc|gmh|ein}} ** {{desc|gsw|ain|alts=1}}, {{l|gsw|a}}, {{l|gsw|an}}, {{l|gsw|en}} ** {{desc|bar|a}} **: {{desc|cim|ummaz|alts=1}} ** {{desc|gmw-cfr|-}} **: Ripuarian: {{l|gmw-cfr|ne}} ** {{desc|gmw-ecg|ä}}, {{l|gmw-ecg|e}} ** {{desc|de|ein}} ** {{desc|lb|een}} ** {{desc|gmw-rfr|-}} **: Hessian: {{l|gmw-rfr|e}} ** {{desc|yi|איין}}, {{l|yi|אַ}}, {{l|yi|אַן}} ---- ==Welsh== ===Etymology=== From {{inh|cy|wlm|yn}}. ===Pronunciation=== * {{a|standard}} {{IPA|cy|/ei̯n/}} ** {{a|colloquial}} {{IPA|cy|/ən/}} ===Determiner=== {{head|cy|determiner|cat2=possessive determiners}} # [[our]] #: {{uxi|cy|'''ein''' gwlad|our land}} # [[us]] {{q|as the object of a verbal noun}} #: {{uxi|cy|'''ein''' gweld|to see us}} ====Usage notes==== {{m|cy|ni|Ni}} is sometimes added after the noun. ---- ==West Frisian== ===Etymology 1=== {{rfe|fy}} ====Noun==== {{fy-noun|c|einen|eintsje}} # {{topics|fy|Anatids}} [[duck]] =====Further reading===== * {{R:WFT|19812|I}} ===Etymology 2=== {{rfe|fy}} ====Noun==== {{fy-noun|c|g2=n|einen|eintsje}} # [[end]] =====Further reading===== * {{R:WFT|19813|II}}
